section.title: The span of a set of vectors

introduction.p: Matrix multiplication allows us to rewrite a linear system in the form A\xvec = \bvec. Besides being a more compact way of expressing a linear system, this form allows us to think about linear systems geometrically since matrix multiplication is defined in terms of linear combinations of vectors.

We now return to our
two fundamental questions,
rephrased here in terms of matrix multiplication.
Existence: Is there a solution to the equation A\xvec=\bvec?
Uniqueness: If there is a solution to the equation A\xvec=\bvec, is it unique?
In this section, we focus on the existence question and see how it leads to the concept of the span of a set of vectors.

li.p: If the equation A\xvec = \bvec is inconsistent, what can we say about the pivot positions of the augmented matrix \left[\begin{array}{r|r} A \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]?

Consider the matrix A
A = \left[ \begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ -2 \amp 2 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp -3 \end{array}\right] . If \bvec=\threevec{2}{2}{5}, is the equation A\xvec = \bvec consistent? If so, find a solution.
If \bvec=\threevec{2}{2}{6}, is the equation A\xvec = \bvec consistent? If so, find a solution.
Identify the pivot positions of A.
For our two choices of the vector \bvec, one equation A\xvec = \bvec has a solution and the other does not. What feature of the pivot positions of the matrix A tells us to expect this?
We know there must be a pivot position in the rightmost column of the augmented matrix.

Now the augmented matrix is
\left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \amp 2 \\ -2 \amp 2 \amp 2 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp -3 \amp 6 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right]
showing that the equation A\xvec=\bvec is inconsistent.

There are two pivot positions in A, as shown.
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} {\mathbf 1} \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ -2 \amp {\mathbf 2} \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp -3 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} {\mathbf 1} \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp {\mathbf 1} \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}

Since there is a row of A that does not have a pivot position, it is possible to augment A by a vector \bvec so that we obtain a pivot position in the rightmost column of the augmented matrix. In this case, we have an inconsistent system.

subsection.title: The span of a set of vectors
subsection.p: In the preview activity, we considered a 3\times3 matrix A and found that the equation A\xvec = \bvec has a solution for some vectors \bvec in \real^3 and has no solution for others. We will introduce a concept called span that describes the vectors \bvec for which there is a solution.

We can write an m\times n matrix A in terms of its columns
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\cdots\amp\vvec_n \end{array}\right] . Remember that says that the equation A\xvec = \bvec is consistent if and only if we can express \bvec as a linear combination of \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n.

definition.p: The span of a set of vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n is the set of all linear combinations that can be formed from the vectors.

Alternatively, if A = \begin{bmatrix} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \cdots \amp \vvec_n \end{bmatrix}, then the span of the vectors consists of all vectors \bvec for which the equation A\xvec = \bvec is consistent.

statement.p:
To determine whether the vector \bvec=\twovec{5}{2} is in the span of \vvec and \wvec, we form the matrix
A = \begin{bmatrix} \vvec \amp \wvec \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -2 \amp 8 \\ 1 \amp -4 \\ \end{bmatrix}
and consider the equation A\xvec=\bvec. We have
\left[ \begin{array}{rr|r} -2 \amp 8 \amp 5 \\ 1 \amp -4 \amp 2 \\ \end{array} \right] \sim \left[ \begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp -4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array} \right],
which shows that the equation A\xvec = \bvec is inconsistent. Therefore, \bvec=\twovec52 is one vector that is not in the span of \vvec and \wvec.

subsection.p: This activity aims to convey the geometric meaning of span. Remember that we can think of a linear combination of the two vectors \vvec and \wvec as a recipe for walking in the plane \real^2. We first move a prescribed amount in the direction of \vvec and then a prescribed amount in the direction of \wvec. The span consists of all the places we can walk to.

statement.p:
Let's consider the vectors \vvec=\twovec20 and \wvec=\twovec{-1}1 as shown in .
The vectors \vvec and \wvec and some linear combinations they create.

The figure shows us that \bvec = \vvec + 2\wvec = \twovec02 is a linear combination of \vvec and \wvec. Indeed, we can verify this algebraically by constructing the linear system
\begin{bmatrix}\vvec \amp \wvec \end{bmatrix} ~ \xvec = \twovec02,
whose corresponding augmented matrix has the reduced row echelon form
\left[ \begin{array}{rr|r} 2 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ \end{array} \right] \sim \left[ \begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ \end{array} \right].
Because this system is consistent, we know that \bvec=\twovec02 is in the span of \vvec and \wvec.

In fact, we can say more. Notice that the coefficient matrix
\begin{bmatrix} 2 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix} \sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}
has a pivot position in every row. This means that for any other vector \bvec, the augmented matrix corresponding to the equation \begin{bmatrix}\vvec \amp \wvec \end{bmatrix} ~\xvec = \bvec cannot have a pivot position in its rightmost column:
\left[ \begin{array}{rr|r} 2 \amp -1 \amp * \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp * \\ \end{array} \right] \sim \left[ \begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp * \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp * \\ \end{array} \right].
Therefore, the equation \begin{bmatrix}\vvec \amp \wvec \end{bmatrix} ~\xvec = \bvec is consistent for every two-dimensional vector \bvec, which tells us that every two-dimensional vector is in the span of \vvec and \wvec. In this case, we say that the span of \vvec and \wvec is \real^2.
The intuitive meaning is that we can walk to any point in the plane by moving an appropriate distance in the \vvec and \wvec directions.

Now let's consider the vectors \vvec=\twovec{-1}1 and \wvec=\twovec2{-2} as shown in .
The vectors \vvec and \wvec and some linear combinations they create.

From the figure, we expect that \bvec = \twovec02 is not a linear combination of \vvec and \wvec. Once again, we can verify this algebraically by constructing the linear system
\begin{bmatrix}\vvec \amp \wvec \end{bmatrix} ~ \xvec = \twovec02.
The augmented matrix has the reduced row echelon form
\left[ \begin{array}{rr|r} -1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp -2 \amp 2 \\ \end{array} \right] \sim \left[ \begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp -2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array} \right],
from which we see that the system is inconsistent. Therefore, \bvec=\twovec02 is not in the span of \vvec and \wvec.

We should expect this behavior from the coefficient matrix
\begin{bmatrix} -1 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp -2 \\ \end{bmatrix} \sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}.
Because the second row of the coefficient matrix does not have a pivot position, it is possible for a linear system \begin{bmatrix}\vvec \amp \wvec \end{bmatrix} ~\xvec = \bvec to have a pivot position in its rightmost column:
\left[ \begin{array}{rr|r} -1 \amp 2 \amp * \\ 1 \amp -2 \amp * \\ \end{array} \right] \sim \left[ \begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp -2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array} \right].

If we notice that \wvec = -2\vvec, we see that any linear combination of \vvec and \wvec,
c\vvec + d\wvec = c\vvec -2d\vvec = (c-2d)\vvec,
is actually a scalar multiple of \vvec. Therefore, the span of \vvec and \wvec is the line defined by the vector \vvec. Intuitively, this means that we can only walk to points on this line using these two vectors.

convention.p: We will denote the span of the set of vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n by \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n}.

subsection.p: In , we saw that \laspan{\vvec,\wvec} = \real^2. However, for the vectors in , we saw that \laspan{\vvec,\wvec} is simply a line.

subsection.title: Pivot positions and span
subsection.p: A set of vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n naturally defines a matrix A = \begin{bmatrix}\vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\cdots\vvec_n\end{bmatrix} whose columns are the given vectors. As we've seen, a vector \bvec is in \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n} precisely when the linear system A\xvec=\bvec is consistent.

The previous examples point to the fact that the span is related to the pivot positions of A. While
and develop this idea more fully, we will now examine the possibilities in \real^3.

statement.p:
In this activity, we will look at the span of sets of vectors in \real^3.
Suppose \vvec=\threevec{1}{2}{1}. Give a geometric description of \laspan{\vvec} and a rough sketch of \vvec and its span in .
A three-dimensional coordinate system for sketching \vvec and its span.
Now consider the two vectors
\evec_1 = \threevec{1}{0}{0},~~~ \evec_2 = \threevec{0}{1}{0} . Sketch the vectors below. Then give a geometric description of \laspan{\evec_1,\evec_2} and a rough sketch of the span in .
A coordinate system for sketching \evec_1, \evec_2, and \laspan{\evec_1,\evec_2}.
Let's now look at this situation algebraically by writing write \bvec = \threevec{b_1}{b_2}{b_3}. Determine the conditions on b_1, b_2, and b_3 so that \bvec is in \laspan{\evec_1,\evec_2} by considering the linear system
\left[\begin{array}{rr} \evec_1 \amp \evec_2 \\ \end{array}\right] ~\xvec = \bvec
or
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \xvec = \threevec{b_1}{b_2}{b_3} . Explain how this relates to your sketch of \laspan{\evec_1,\evec_2}.
Consider the vectors
\vvec_1 = \threevec{1}{1}{-1},~~ \vvec_2 = \threevec{0}{2}{1}.
Is the vector \bvec=\threevec{1}{-2}{4} in \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}?
Is the vector \bvec=\threevec{-2}{0}{3} in \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}?
Give a geometric description of \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}.
Consider the vectors
\vvec_1 = \threevec{1}{1}{-1}, \vvec_2 = \threevec{0}{2}{1}, \vvec_3 = \threevec{1}{-2}{4} . Form the matrix \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \vvec_3 \end{array}\right] and find its reduced row echelon form.
What does this tell you about \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}?
If the span of a set of vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n is \real^3, what can you say about the pivot positions of the matrix \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\ldots\amp\vvec_n \end{array}\right]?
What is the smallest number of vectors such that \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n} = \real^3?

li.p: For the linear system to be consistent, we need b_3=0, which means that the third coordinate of the vector \bvec must be 0 for \bvec to be in \laspan{\evec_1,\evec_2}. In other words, \bvec must lie in the xy-plane.

We consider the two cases.
We have the augmented matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp -2 \\ -1 \amp 1 \amp 4 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right]\text{,}
which shows that the system is inconsistent. Therefore, \bvec is not in \laspan{\vvec_1, \vvec_2}.
We have the augmented matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp 1 \amp 3 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right]\text{,}
which shows that the system is consistent. Therefore, \bvec is in \laspan{\vvec_1, \vvec_2}.
The span is the plane in \real^3 defined by \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.
There must be a pivot position in every row.

If a set of vectors spans \real^3, its corresponding matrix must have a pivot position in every row. Because there can be at most one pivot position in a column, there must be at least three columns. Therefore, the smallest number of vectors that span \real^3 is three.

subsection.p:
The types of sets that appear as the span of a set of vectors in \real^3 are relatively simple.
First, with a single nonzero vector, all linear combinations are simply scalar multiples of that vector so that the span of this vector is a line, as shown in .
The span of a single nonzero vector is a line.
Notice that the matrix formed by this vector has one pivot position. For example,
\threevec{-2}{3}{1} \sim \threevec{1}{0}{0} .
The span of two vectors in \real^3 that do not lie on the same line will be a plane, as seen in .
The span of these two vectors in \real^3 is a plane.
For example, the vectors
\vvec_1=\threevec{-2}{3}{1},~~~ \vvec_2=\threevec{1}{-1}{3}
lead to the matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rr} -2 \amp 1 \\ 3 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]
with two pivot positions.
Finally, a set of three vectors, such as
\vvec_1=\threevec12{-1},~~~ \vvec_2=\threevec201,~~~ \vvec_3=\threevec{-2}20
may form a matrix having three pivot positions
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \vvec_3 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp -2 \\ 2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ -1 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right],
one in every row. When this happens, no matter how we augment this matrix, it is impossible to obtain a pivot position in the rightmost column:
\left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 2 \amp -2 \amp *\\ 2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp * \\ -1 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp * \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp *\\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp * \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp * \\ \end{array}\right].
Therefore, any linear system \begin{bmatrix}\vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\vvec_3\end{bmatrix} ~\xvec = \bvec is consistent, which tells us that \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} = \real^3.

To summarize, we looked at the pivot positions in a matrix whose columns are the three-dimensional vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n. We found that with
one pivot position, the span was a line.
two pivot positions, the span was a plane.
three pivot positions, the span was \real^3.
Though we will return to these ideas later, for now take note of the fact that the span of a set of vectors in \real^3 is a relatively simple, familiar geometric object.
The reasoning that led us to conclude that the span of a set of vectors is \real^3 when the associated matrix has a pivot position in every row applies more generally.

statement.p: Suppose we have vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n in \real^m. Then \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n}=\real^m if and only if the matrix \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\cdots\amp\vvec_n \end{array}\right] has a pivot position in every row.

subsection.p:
This tells us something important about the number of vectors needed to span \real^m. Suppose we have n vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n that span \real^m. The proposition tells us that the matrix A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\ldots\amp\vvec_n \end{array}\right] has a pivot position in every row, such as in this reduced row echelon matrix.
\left[\begin{array}{rrrrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp * \amp 0 \amp * \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp * \amp 0 \amp * \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp * \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right].
Since a matrix can have at most one pivot position in a column, there must be at least as many columns as there are rows, which implies that n\geq m. For instance, if we have a set of vectors that span \real^{632}, there must be at least 632 vectors in the set.

statement.p: A set of vectors whose span is \real^m contains at least m vectors.

subsection.p: We have thought about a linear combination of a set of vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n as the result of walking a certain distance in the direction of \vvec_1, followed by walking a certain distance in the direction of \vvec_2, and so on. If \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n} = \real^m, this means that we can walk to every point in \real^m using the directions \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n. Intuitively, this proposition is telling us that we need at least m directions to have the flexibility needed to reach every point in \real^m.

assemblage.title: Terminology
assemblage.p: Because span is a concept that is connected to a set of vectors, we say, The span of the set of vectors \vvec_1, \vvec_2, \ldots, \vvec_n is .... While it may be tempting to say, The span of the matrix A is ..., we should instead say The span of the columns of the matrix A is ....

subsection.title: Summary
subsection.p:
We defined the span of a set of vectors and developed some intuition for this concept through a series of examples.
The span of a set of vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n is the set of linear combinations of the vectors. We denote the span by \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n}.
A vector \bvec is in \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n} if and only if the linear system
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\ldots\vvec_n \end{array}\right] ~\xvec = \bvec
is consistent.
If the m\times n matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\ldots\vvec_n \end{array}\right]
has a pivot position in every row, then the span of these vectors is \real^m; that is, \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n} = \real^m.
Any set of vectors that spans \real^m must have at least m vectors.

statement.p: If \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3 are nonzero vectors in \real^4 and \laspan{\vvec_1, \vvec_2,\vvec_3} is a line, what can you say about the vectors \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3? Explain your thinking.

introduction.p: Suppose that A is a 4\times3 matrix whose columns are \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3 and that \bvec is a vector in \real^4.

statement.p: If \bvec is in \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} , what can we conclude about the set of solutions to the equation A\xvec = \bvec? Explain your thinking.
If 2\vvec_1-\vvec_2+3\vvec_3 = \bvec, what can we say about the relationship between \bvec and \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}? Explain your thinking.

exercise.title: Connecting span with reduced row echelon form

statement.p:
Suppose that \vvec_1, \vvec_2, \vvec_3, \vvec_4 are vectors in \real^3. The matrices in the left column are some possible reduced row echelon forms for the matrix
\begin{bmatrix} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\vvec_3\amp\vvec_4 \end{bmatrix} . If possible, match the matrices to the corresponding geometric object for \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2, \vvec_3, \vvec_4}. Note that not all geometric objects correspond to a matrix, and some geometric objects may correspond to more than one matrix.
Determine whether each of the statements in the left column is always true, always false, or sometimes true.

match.premise: If \bvec is in \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_1+\vvec_2}, then \bvec is in \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}.
If \vvec_1,\ldots,\vvec_{22} is a set of 22 vectors in \real^{23}, then \laspan{\vvec_1,\ldots,\vvec_{22}}=\real^{23}.
If \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 are vectors in \real^3, then \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2} is a plane.
If \vvec_1,\ldots,\vvec_{n} are vectors in \real^{23} and \laspan{\vvec_1,\ldots,\vvec_{n}}=\real^{23}, then n=23.
